The first night, the camp director

128.18.text:
"Kids, we have a very
international camp this year;

132.17.text: the Atencios are here from Venezuela."

135.92.text:
The other kids looked at us
as if we were from another planet.

139.89.text: They would ask us things like,

142.01.text: "Do you know what a hamburger is?"

144.09.text:
Or, "Do you go to school

148.70.text:
I would try to answer
in my broken English,

152.67.text: I know they were not trying to be mean;

154.80.text:
they were just trying
to understand who we were,

157.27.text:
and make a correlation
with the world they knew.

160.35.text: We could either be like them,

161.87.text:
or like characters out of a book
filled with adventures,

164.90.text: like Aladdin or the Jungle Book.

167.60.text: We certainly didn't look like them,

172.69.text: When you're seven years old, that hurts.

175.75.text:
But I had my little sister
to take care of,

178.47.text: and she cried every day at summer camp.

181.12.text: So I decided to put on a brave face,

183.79.text:
and embrace everything I could
about the American way of life.

188.06.text:
We later did what we called
"the summer camp experiment,"

191.37.text:
for eight years in different cities
that many Americans haven't even heard of.

197.08.text:
What I remember most about these moments
was when I finally clicked with someone.

202.23.text: Making a friend was a special reward.

206.20.text:
Everybody wants to feel
valued and accepted,

208.90.text:
and we think it should happen
spontaneously, but it doesn't.

213.26.text:
When you're different,
you have to work at belonging.

217.25.text:
You have to be either
really helpful, smart, funny,

220.99.text:
anything to be cool for the crowd
you want to hang out with.

225.49.text: Later on, when I was in high school,

227.33.text: my dad expanded on his summer plan,

230.30.text:
and from Caracas he sent me
to Wallingford, Connecticut,

233.79.text: for the senior year of high school.

236.06.text:
This time, I remember
daydreaming on the plane

239.05.text:
about "the American high school

243.89.text: It was going to be perfect,

245.21.text:
just like in my favorite TV show:
"Saved by the Bell."

249.80.text: I get there, and they tell me

251.50.text:
that my assigned roommate

256.64.text: and there she was, sitting on the bed,

262.38.text:
Her name was Fatima,
and she was Muslim from Bahrain,

265.37.text: and she was not what I expected.

268.09.text:
She probably sensed my disappointment
when I looked at her

271.07.text: because I didn't do too much to hide it.

274.89.text:
See, as a teenager,
I wanted to fit in even more,

279.43.text: maybe have a boyfriend for prom,

282.47.text: and I felt that Fatima just got in the way

285.09.text:
with her shyness
and her strict dress code.

289.33.text:
I didn't realize
that I was making her feel

292.12.text: like the kids at summer camp made me feel.

294.76.text:
This was the high school
equivalent of asking her,

297.54.text: "Do you know what a hamburger is?"

300.26.text: I was consumed by my own selfishness

302.54.text: and unable to put myself in her shoes.

306.50.text: I have to be honest with you,

308.69.text:
we only lasted a couple
of months together,

because she was later sent
to live with a counselor

You see, when we label
someone as different,

323.74.text: it dehumanizes them in a way.

327.94.text:
They're not worthy of our time,
not our problem,

331.02.text:
and in fact, they, "the other,"
are probably the cause of our problems.

337.28.text: So, how do we recognize our blind spots?

340.47.text:
It begins by understanding
what makes you different,

347.61.text:
Only then can you begin to appreciate
what makes others special.

352.91.text: I remember when this hit me.

356.81.text: I had found that boyfriend for prom,

until everybody signed on to participate

others were going to recite

381.25.text:
"We don't practice talents

I was painfully aware

The only way to do it,

Yes, they broke a law,

I've already told you how my path

777.28.text:
To end, I want to tell you how I hit
the worst bump in the road yet,

782.11.text: one that shook me to my very core.

789.41.text:
I was driving to the studio,

793.58.text: "Are you on the air?" they asked.

800.37.text:
"It's your sister;
she's been in a car accident."

804.91.text: It was as if my heart stopped.

809.27.text: My hands gripped the steering wheel,

811.50.text: and I remember hearing the words:

813.50.text: "It is unlikely she will ever walk again."

817.58.text:
They say your life can change
in a split second.

824.22.text:
My sister went from being
my successful other half,

828.04.text: only a year apart in age,

829.93.text: to not being able to move her legs,

833.62.text: sit up, or get dressed by herself.

837.10.text:
This wasn't like summer camp,

843.94.text:
Throughout the course of two years,

848.69.text:
and she spent the most
of that time in a wheelchair.

852.17.text: But that wasn't even the worst of it.

854.75.text:
The worst was something so painful,
it's hard to put into words, even now.

861.07.text: It was the way people looked at her,

868.50.text:
People were unable to see
a successful lawyer

872.95.text:
or a millennial with a sharp wit
and a kind heart.

879.55.text:
I realized that people just saw
a poor girl in a wheelchair.

883.18.text:
They were unable to see
anything beyond that.

890.39.text:
I can thankfully tell you
that today my sister is walking,

895.15.text:
and has recovered
beyond anyone's expectations.

905.15.text:
I learned there are differences
that simply suck,

908.75.text: and it's hard to find positive in them.

911.55.text:
My sister's not better off
because of what happened.

915.86.text:
But she taught me: you can't let
those differences define you.

922.51.text:
Being able to reimagine yourself
beyond what other people see,

928.24.text: that is the toughest task of all,

930.89.text: but it's also the most beautiful.
